Articles.Content: Is it more efficent to point at the manevore node while burning or more efficent while holding prograde.

Technically speaking, a burn is always the most efficient if it's pointing perfectly prograde the whole time.  When you're not pointing prograde, you're subject to cosine losses.

However, it can be difficult in KSP to hit your target accurately if you stick perfectly to prograde (hard to figure out exactly where to start the burn).

In practice, this only becomes an issue when you have a very very low TWR craft (e.g. a single LV-N pushing a very massive vessel, or an ion ship) that has a really long burn time.  That's because if the burn time is short (for example, you're leaving LKO and your burn time is under 2 minutes), then prograde is so close to the maneuver node that the cosine losses are neglible and you don't need to worry about them much.

We had a big discussion about this last year, I suggest you take a look at the thread.  The conclusion was that burning prograde is a little more efficient in terms of Δv, but the savings are small.  What we found to be more important is that following the maneuver node is more accurate than burning prograde.  That is, the orbit that is calculated when you place a maneuver node is the theoretical orbit produced when the Δv is added instantaneously at the location of the maneuver node.  If you follow the common practice of centering your burn on the maneuver node (i.e. 1/2 burn time before node, and 1/2 burn time after node), then keeping aligned to the maneuver node marker on the NavBall results in a orbit that is closer to the theoretical orbit than had you kept aligned to the prograde marker.  I find that I would much rather have greater accuracy then save a few m/s Δv that I'm likely to burn through anyway by having to perform a course correction.
